metadata.title: Serial interval of novel coronavirus (COVID-19) infections
metadata.abstract:
Objective
To estimate the serial interval of novel coronavirus (COVID-19) from information on 28 infector-infectee pairs.
Methods
We collected dates of illness onset for primary cases (infectors) and secondary cases (infectees) from published research articles and case investigation reports. We subjectively ranked the credibility of the data and performed analyses on both the full dataset (n = 28) and a subset of pairs with highest certainty in reporting (n = 18). In addition, we adjust for right truncation of the data as the epidemic is still in its growth phase.
metadata.author: Hiroshi Nishiura, Natalie M. Linton, Andrei R. Akhmetzhanov

objective: To estimate the serial interval of novel coronavirus (COVID-19) from information on 28 infector-infectee pairs.
methods: We collected dates of illness onset for primary cases (infectors) and secondary cases (infectees) from published research articles and case investigation reports. We subjectively ranked the credibility of the data and performed analyses on both the full dataset (n = 28) and a subset of pairs with highest certainty in reporting (n = 18). In addition, we adjust for right truncation of the data as the epidemic is still in its growth phase.
results: Accounting for right truncation and analyzing all pairs, we estimated the median serial interval at 4.0 days (95% credible interval [CrI]: 3.1, 4.9). Limiting our data to only the most certain pairs, the median serial interval was estimated at 4.6 days (95% CrI: 3.5, 5.9).
conclusions: The serial interval of COVID-19 is close to or shorter than its median incubation period. This suggests that a substantial proportion of secondary transmission may occur prior to illness onset. The COVID-19 serial interval is also shorter than the serial interval of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), indicating that calculations made using the SARS serial interval may introduce bias.
introduction: We collected dates of illness onset for primary cases (infectors) and secondary cases (infectees) from published research articles and case investigation reports. We subjectively ranked the credibility of the data and performed analyses on both the full dataset (n = 28) and a subset of pairs with highest certainty in reporting (n = 18). In addition, we adjust for right truncation of the data as the epidemic is still in its growth phase

Objective: To estimate the serial interval of novel coronavirus (COVID-19) from information on 28 infector-infectee pairs.
Methods: We collected dates of illness onset for primary cases (infectors) and secondary cases (infectees) from published research articles and case investigation reports. We subjectively ranked the credibility of the data and performed analyses on both the full dataset (n = 28) and a subset of pairs with highest certainty in reporting (n = 18). In addition, we adjust for right truncation of the data as the epidemic is still in its growth phase.
Results: Accounting for right truncation and analyzing all pairs, we estimated the median serial interval at 4.0 days (95% credible interval [CrI]: 3.1, 4.9). Limiting our data to only the most certain pairs, the median serial interval was estimated at 4.6 days (95% CrI: 3.5, 5.9).
Conclusions: The serial interval of COVID-19 is close to or shorter than its median incubation period. This suggests that a substantial proportion of secondary transmission may occur prior to illness onset. The COVID-19 serial interval is also shorter than the serial interval of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), indicating that calculations made using the SARS serial interval may introduce bias.

Methods. <mark class="stats">The serial interval of novel coronavirus (COVID-19) infections was estimated from a total of 28 infector-infectee pairs</mark>. The median serial interval is shorter than the median incubation period, suggesting a substantial proportion of pre-symptomatic transmission

A short serial interval makes it difficult to trace contacts due to the rapid turnover of case generations. <mark class="stats">To estimate the serial interval of novel coronavirus (COVID-19) from information on 28 infector-infectee pairs</mark>. We collected dates of illness onset for primary cases (infectors) and secondary cases (infectees) from published research articles and case investigation reports

summary:
Introduction:

The authors collected dates of illness onset for primary cases and secondary cases from published research articles and case investigation reports.
The authors subjectively ranked the credibility of the data and performed analyses on both the full dataset (n = 28) and a subset of pairs with highest certainty in reporting (n = 18).
The authors adjust for right truncation of the data as the epidemic is still in its growth phase

Methods:

The authors collected dates of illness onset for primary cases and secondary cases from published research articles and case investigation reports.
The authors subjectively ranked the credibility of the data and performed analyses on both the full dataset (n = 28) and a subset of pairs with highest certainty in reporting (n = 18).
The authors adjust for right truncation of the data as the epidemic is still in its growth phase

Results:

Accounting for right truncation and analyzing all pairs, the authors estimated the median serial interval at 4.0 days (95% credible interval [CrI]: 3.1, 4.9).
Limiting the data to only the most certain pairs, the median serial interval was estimated at 4.6 days (95% CrI: 3.5, 5.9)

Conclusion:

The serial interval of COVID-19 is close to or shorter than its median incubation period.
This suggests that a substantial proportion of secondary transmission may occur prior to illness onset.
The COVID-19 serial interval is shorter than the serial interval of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), indicating that calculations made using the SARS serial interval may introduce bias
